unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: Type II Error in Context
question_text: A study on womenâ€™s weights was recently completed. Fifteen randomly selected high school females from an urban setting were compared to $16$ randomly selected high school females from a rural setting. The results are below: Two-Sample T for Urban Weights vs. Rural Weights N Mean StDev SE Mean Urban Weights 15 126.1 10.5 2.7 Rural Weights 16 128.8 13.2 3.3 Difference = $\mu$ (Urban Weights) - $\mu$ (Rural Weights) Estimate for difference: $-2.68$ $95\%$ CI for difference: $(-11.45, 6.09)$ $T$ -test of difference = $0$ (vs. not =): $T$ -value = $-0.63$ $P$ -value = $0.537$ DF = $28$ A type II error in the context of this study would involve

choices.text: Implying there is no difference in urban versus rural weights, when really there is a difference.
Implying there is a difference in urban versus rural weights, when really there is no difference.
Implying the difference between urban and rural weights is 2.68 2.68 \text{ pounds}$, when in fact it is more.
Implying the difference between urban and rural weights is 2.68 pounds 2.68 pounds , when in fact it is less.
Implying there is no difference in urban versus rural weights, when in fact there really is no difference.
